Though SHG (second harmonic generation) requires a material to have specific molecular orientation in order for the incident light to be frequency doubled, some biological materials can be highly polarizable, and assemble into fairly ordered, large noncentrosymmetric structures. Biological materials such as collagen, microtubules, and muscle myosin can produce SHG signals.And I think since they have the X(2) susceptibility, also  the reverse of SHG,  the parametric fluorescence or how you call it SPDC or  entangled photon pair generation. Using SHG imagining microscopy, they even made an image of collagen in liver. SHG is a nonlinear optical process in which two photons with the same frequency interact with a nonlinear material, are "combined", and generate a new photon with twice the energy of the initial photons

How is it that a photon, an elementary particle, can be split?

The problem here is in the concepts. Quantum mechanics is all about how a wave phenomenon can in certain circumstances, manifest itself in a localized, quantized, form. This happens especially when certain kinds of observations are made. But light is propagated as a wave.

A popular misconception is that physical reality is "really" a bunch of particles. This is wrong, does not agree with observation, and contrary to quantum mechanics, in which physical is in some circumstances best described in terms of waves, and other circumstances in terms in particles (and sometimes it gets messy).

There is no problem with the picture of a wave being split. When an observation is made, the phenomenon is manifested as two particles. It's a matter of how you look at the thing.

The incoming photon is not absorbed into the crystal. That's the magic of these crystals. They can be used as amplifiers in a process called (optical parametric amplification) you can reach extrem amplification per unit length (1-10mio per mm). The crystal is just a catalyst and does not get hot. That's why this works at all. It's a really amazing process.
Oh and as a bonus you can amplify pretty much any wavelength longer than your pump wavelength. It's tunable.

Down conversion is the same process, without providing a second beam for amplification.

A photon is basically a small packet of radio waves. Therefore, splitting one results in two with half the energy of the original, and in wave terms lower energy equals lower frequency, or longer wavelength. Or, combining two results in a shorter wavelength. Hence the color change.

Of course at the atomic scale all of these objects behave both like particles and like waves, and at the same time too.

I was thinking UV lasers already exist. The green lasers are actually a frequency doubler starting from infrared. The UV variant is a frequency tripler. These lasers are not tunable.
Another laser on which I worked as software engineer is the Maitai which uses a green laser as energy source (called "pump") and produce ultra fast pulses of light tunable from 700 nm to 1000 nm, with the most efficient peak at 800 nm. This range is all in the infrared region, but being short pulses of 20 femto second, a square wave pulse with a duty cycle of 0.1% (1 part on, 999 part off), the fourier transform instruct us that many higher frequency harmonic may be present.

Dianna, not entirely related, but you should look up the 'sun stone' Vikings would use to help guide them and see the sun when it was cloudy. It was a crystal that would polarize the light. They would mark one side of it with a dot (tar, paint, or whatever) When they would look through the side opposite of the mark, they would see two dots. the dots would get closer together when they were closer to looking at the sun. And when they were looking at the sun, the dots would stack. This would help them navigate storms or clouds on the oceans.

Yes, human eyes can detect single photons. I read the paper establishing this in an MIT course back in the dark ages (early 1970s). The researchers used themselves as test subjects and figured out that human eyes really aren't so transparent, which causes most of the variation in whether a few-photon flash is seen. One photon can change a cis carbon-carbon double bond to trans, which opens up the protein to expose a reactive group that water hits to generate enough energy to fire a nerve cell in the retina, and after that it's easy, so the brain is soon saying, "Hey! I saw a little flash!"

+Physics Girl 3:11 How? Even if you assume that the crystal and the whole setup is infinitely massive compared to the energy of a photon so that the energy lost in recoil is zero and there is no other energy loss, you can't send the 'daughter photons' in two different directions.
Because for a photon E = p*c (p = magnitude of a photon's momentum). So If the 'mother photon' had momentum (p1,0,0) and energy p1*c, the daughters have total x-momentum = p1 and energy p1*c. So the daughters leaving along x axis would satisfy the energy and momentum conservation. But if they also have (say) any y-momentum then the daughters will have more combined energy than the mother, violating the energy conservation.
And if the crystal recoils, matters become even worse.

I'm not sure I really see the big deal here. Isn't this crystal just a very, very slightly angled prism? Photons are waves too, not just particles. So you're really just cutting the wave into two lower frequency waves. This is how all prisms work, such as when you shine white light into a normal prism, and out comes multi-colored light that has been "split". This crystal just does it on a very small scale.
